subsection.title: "Clearing" Fractions
subsection.p: How can we solve an equation that involves algebraic fractions? Recall that to solve the equation \dfrac{3x}{4} = 9 we multiply both sides by 4 (the denominator of the fraction) to "clear" the fraction. \cancel{\blert{4}}(\dfrac{3x}{\cancel{4}}) \amp = (9)\blert{4} 3x \amp = 36 We can now finish the solution to get x=12.
We use the same idea to solve an equation with algebraic fractions.

solution.p: We multiply both sides of the equation by x, the denominator of the fraction, to get \cancel{\blert{x}}(\dfrac{5000+50x}{\cancel{x}}) \amp = (75)\blert{x} 5000+50x \amp = 75x Then we proceed as usual to finish the solution. We subtract 50x from both sides to find 5000 \amp = 25x 200 \amp = x You can check that x=200 does satisfy the equation.

subsection.title: Using an LCD to Clear Fractions
subsection.p: If an equation contains more than one fraction, we multiply both sides of the equation by the LCD of all the fractions. This will clear all the denominators at once.

warning.p: In Example 2, note that we multiplied each term by the LCD, 15, including terms that are not fractions, namely 2 in this example. Be sure to multiply each term of the equation by the LCD.

statement.p: When clearing fractions, which terms of the equation should we multiply by the LCD?

subsection.title: Variables in the Denominator
subsection.p: Equations that involve algebraic fractions can also be solved using an LCD.

solution.p: The LCD for the two fractions in the equation is \blert{4(x-5)}. We multiply both sides of the equation by the LCD. \blert{4(x-5)}(\dfrac{3}{4}) \amp = (8- \dfrac{2x+11}{x-5}) \cdot \blert{4(x-5)} ~~~~~~~~ \blert{\text{Apply the distributive law.}} \blert{\cancel{4}(x-5)}(\dfrac{3}{\cancel{4}}) \amp = \blert{4(x-5)}(8)- \blert{4\cancel{(x-5)}}(\dfrac{2x+11}{x-5}) 3(x-5) \amp = 32(x-5)-4(2x+11) We proceed as usual to complete the solution. First we use the distributive law to remove parentheses. 3x-15 \amp = 32x-160-8x-44 \amp \amp \blert{\text{Combine like terms.}} 3x-15 \amp = 24x-204 -21x \amp = -189 x \amp = 9 The solution is x=9. You can check that x=9 satisfies the original equation.

statement.p: How do we "clear" the fractions from an equation?

answer.p: Multiply both sides by the LCD.

assemblage.title: Look Ahead
assemblage.p: Remember that we do not obtain an equivalent equation if we multiply both sides of an equation by zero. In Example 3 we multiplied by 4(x-5). Is it possible that 4(x-5) equals zero? After solving, we found that x=9, so 4(x-5) = 16, which is not zero, and the multiplication step was valid. The next example illustrates what can go wrong if we multiply by zero.

subsection.title: Extraneous Solutions
subsection.p: In Example 4, when we multiplied both sides of the equation by zero we found a false solution for the equation. Such solutions are called extraneous solutions. There is always a danger that an extraneous solution may be introduced when we multiply by an expression that contains the variable.

statement.p: When might an extraneous solution be introduced?

answer.p: When we multiply by an expression that contains the variable.

assemblage.p: We should always check for extraneous solutions when solving equations that involve algebraic fractions.

subsection.p: To check a solution, we substitute it into the original equation. If a possible solution causes any of the denominators in the equation to equal zero, then that solution is extraneous.

statement.p: How do we check for extraneous solutions?

answer.p: See if it causes any of the denominators in the equation to equal zero.

subsection.p: We can also solve formulas that involve algebraic fractions.

subsection.title: Applications

statement.p: A cruise boat travels 18 miles downstream and back in 4\dfrac{1}{2} hours. If the speed of the current is 3 miles per hour, what is the speed of the boat in still water?

solution.p: We let x stand for unknown quantity, the speed of the boat in still water. Then we make a table showing the distance, rate, and time for each part of the trip. We begin by filling in the information given in the problem.
We use the formula t = \dfrac{d}{r} to fill in the last column of the table.
